On 7 Jul 2006, at 20:18, David Saff wrote:

> DMCG123 wrote:
> > Now in junit 4 it looks like the instances of test
classes are
> constructed on the fly. The
> > constructor of each test instance is called just
before @Before.
> >
> > So my question - is this a designed behaviour? Can
I assume that
> junit 4 runners will have
> > this behaviour, allowing me to use the constructor
instead of
> @Before, allowing fields to
> > be final, etc?
> >
>
> Yes, this is designed behavior (as is, in your
second message,
> releasing
> each test object for potential garbage collection
after the test
> completes). You can trust the runners that ship with
JUnit 4 to
> preserve it. If you invoke a custom runner, you're
currently at the
> mercy of that runner's writer.
>
> In my own code, I use constructors in JUnit 4 tests,
unless I'm doing
> something that I want to be visually matched with a
particular @After.

Excellent, thank you.

It wasn't something that I had seen mentioned in the
JUnit 4 write-
ups, and for our suite of 700-odd tests, many of which
are functional
tests which fire up the GUI, talk to the database,
play media with
QuickTime etc, it should increase stability
significantly.

Just waiting now for a decent ant task...;-)

Duncan
